q1e.answer: Since you cannot control how the scheduler choses to assign threads time slices, I see no guarantee that the threads are running at the same time in the 'testSerilizability()' test. q2d.text: Provide comments on why you found any aspects of the correctness argument provided to be lacking, incorrect, or in need of improvement.
q2d.answer: Arguments seems to cover all we can think of, but looking at the code I don't think the locking mechanism work. First little detail, is that the defined writeLock is in fact a readlock. Assuming that you did mean to write "readWriteLock.writeLock()" at line 29. One problem arising multiple places is the premature release of locks. Take addCopies as an example. You use a readlock to check the bookmap contains the appropriate book, but then release the lock before applying the changes. If another operation decides to remove some books, you are in trouble since the correct error is not returned. One possibility is to extend the read lock and upgrade it to a write lock at the appropriate time. But this is deadlock prone as per the textbook. Some kind of write lock is needed all through the operation.

q4a.text: Is there a sound argument about the scalability limits of the concurrent implementation provided?

q4b.text: Provide comments on how the reflections on scalability could be improved
q4b.answer: I think you avoid most scalability problems because the locking protocol does not ensure before-or-after atomicity. As discussed in the answer to question 2, you have to hold write locks for longer. This is a big source of overhead, and write operations suddenly become expensive.
